issues.description: The problem statement and UML specify a parameterless method getTotalNumberOfStudents(): int (students are asked to implement getTotalNumberOfStudents() that returns the total number of students). The solution implementation instead defines getTotalNumberOfStudents(boolean includeGuests) — i.e., it introduces a boolean parameter. This is a signature/parameter mismatch: students following the specification will implement a parameterless method, but the reference solution uses a different signature and calls getTotalNumberOfStudents(true) from other methods. This discrepancy can confuse students when comparing their implementation with the solution (and with the UML/tests) and may cause tests or examples that expect a parameterless method to fail or differ from the solution.
issues.suggested_fix: Make the solution match the problem specification: implement getTotalNumberOfStudents() as a parameterless method that returns the total number of students (e.g., numberOfInscribedStudents + numberOfGuestStudents). If support for an optional includeGuests parameter is desired, add an overloaded method getTotalNumberOfStudents(boolean includeGuests) but keep the parameterless getTotalNumberOfStudents() as the primary API used in the UML and tasks. Update any internal calls (e.g., getNameAndTotalNumberOfStudents(), getNumberOfStudentsPerTutor()) to use the parameterless method to remain consistent with the problem statement and tests.

issues.description: The problem statement and UML specify a no-argument method getTotalNumberOfStudents(): int, but the solution implements getTotalNumberOfStudents(boolean includeGuests). This changes the API students are expected to implement and creates a mapping mismatch: the concept 'total number of students' is described as a simple, parameterless operation in the exercise, while the solution exposes an overloaded/parameterized variant. Students reading the problem or template will expect to implement or call getTotalNumberOfStudents() without parameters and may be confused by the extra boolean parameter in the provided solution.
issues.suggested_fix: Align the solution with the problem specification by providing a no-argument method matching the UML: public int getTotalNumberOfStudents() that returns numberOfInscribedStudents + numberOfGuestStudents. If optional behavior is desired (e.g. excluding guests), add an overloaded method public int getTotalNumberOfStudents(boolean includeGuests) or rename the parameterized variant, but keep the parameterless method so students can directly implement the exercise as specified.
